articles.headline: Immigration Poses Threat of Another Republican Rift
articles.snippet: A push to bring legislation to the House floor, led by a coalition of executives, conservatives and evangelical leaders, could affect campaign contributions before the midterm elections.
articles.abstract: A push to bring legislation to the House floor, led by a coalition of executives, conservatives and evangelical leaders, could affect campaign contributions before the midterm elections.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A push to bring immigration legislation to the House floor, led by an unusual coalition of business executives, prominent conservatives and evangelical leaders, threatens to create another schism in the Republican Party and could have a noticeable effect on campaign contributions before the midterm elections.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton and Ashley Parker

articles.headline: Plan to Tax the Rich Could Aim Higher
articles.snippet: The mayoral candidate Bill de Blasio’s proposal to raise taxes on the city’s wealthy won’t touch many of the wealthiest.
articles.abstract: The mayoral candidate Bill de Blasio’s proposal to raise taxes on the city’s wealthy won’t touch many of the wealthiest.
articles.lead_paragraph: Bill de Blasio has made New York’s “Tale of Two Cities” a centerpiece of his Democratic campaign for mayor. “One New Yorker is rushing past an attended desk in the lobby of a majestic skyscraper,” Mr. de Blasio said in a speech at the New School earlier this year, while “a few miles away, a single mother is also rushing, holding her two young children by the hands as they hurry down the steps of the subway entrance.”

articles.headline: Promised Fix for Health Site Could Squeeze Some Users
articles.snippet: The White House said that it would fix the insurance marketplace by Nov. 30, raising the question of how people whose current policies do not comply with the law will get new coverage in time.
articles.abstract: The White House said that it would fix the insurance marketplace by Nov. 30, raising the question of how people whose current policies do not comply with the law will get new coverage in time.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration said Friday that it would fix problems in the federal health insurance marketplace by Nov. 30, just two weeks before the deadline to sign up for coverage to replace health insurance policies being canceled because they do not meet new federal standards.
articles.byline: By Robert Pear and Sharon LaFraniere

articles.headline: JPMorgan Reaches Deal With Agency Over Loans
articles.snippet: The Federal Housing Finance Agency,which helped forge a tentative $13 billion settlement with JPMorgan Chase split off with its own deal on Friday, extracting a $4 billion payout from the nation’s biggest bank.
articles.abstract: The Federal Housing Finance Agency,which helped forge a tentative $13 billion settlement with JPMorgan Chase split off with its own deal on Friday, extracting a $4 billion payout from the nation’s biggest bank.
articles.lead_paragraph: JPMorgan Chase has secured important concessions in a $13 billion settlement over its mortgage practices, allowances that could ultimately reduce the bank’s financial burden and leave the government itself on the hook for a small portion of the cost.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Peter Eavis

articles.headline: Prices That Fly Under the Headlines
articles.snippet: Those who want to buy art and not spend millions can find works in less-popular forms, like drawings, prints and small sculptures, or by lesser-known but first-rate artists.
articles.abstract: Those who want to buy art and not spend millions can find works in less-popular forms, like drawings, prints and small sculptures, or by lesser-known but first-rate artists.
articles.lead_paragraph: LET us, for the moment anyway, dispense with the phrase “record prices” and forget about all the auction frenzy — the $120 million paid for a pastel by Munch; the $106.5 million for an oil painting by Picasso; the $104.3 million for a Giacometti sculpture. These numbers seem more like money in a Monopoly game than reality.

articles.headline: Roma, Feared as Kidnappers, See Their Own Children at Risk
articles.snippet: Some are worried that their children will be taken away on the notion that all Roma have dark features, as part of a backlash after accusations of kidnapping.
articles.abstract: Some are worried that their children will be taken away on the notion that all Roma have dark features, as part of a backlash after accusations of kidnapping.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — For centuries across Europe, children were raised on folk tales with a disturbing message: Wander into the woods and you risk being snatched by Gypsies.

articles.headline: Bottled Water Sales Rising as Soda Ebbs
articles.snippet: By the end of the decade, sales of water — whether plain, flavored or carbonated — will surpass those of sodas like Coke and Pepsi.
articles.abstract: By the end of the decade, sales of water — whether plain, flavored or carbonated — will surpass those of sodas like Coke and Pepsi.
articles.lead_paragraph: Few things are more American than Coca-Cola.

articles.headline: An Intriguing Product That’s Too Complex for Many
articles.snippet: Alternative mutual funds have been gaining in popularity, but some advisers urge caution.
articles.abstract: Alternative mutual funds have been gaining in popularity, but some advisers urge caution.
articles.lead_paragraph: The sales pitches go something like this: A mutual fund that promises to zig when the rest of the stock market zags. Bond funds that protect investors when interest rates rise. Access to the most sophisticated hedge fund managers in the country, even if you’re not particularly wealthy.

articles.headline: Toyota Agrees to Settlement in Fatal Acceleration Crash
articles.snippet: Legal analysts said the decision could embolden plaintiffs in hundreds of other lawsuits that have been filed against the automaker.
articles.abstract: Legal analysts said the decision could embolden plaintiffs in hundreds of other lawsuits that have been filed against the automaker.
articles.lead_paragraph: Toyota agreed on Friday to a settlement with the families of two women in a fatal crash the morning after an Oklahoma jury became the first to find the company responsible for the unintended acceleration of a car.

articles.headline: Bank’s Midlevel Executive Becomes a New Face of the Housing Crisis
articles.snippet: Rebecca S. Mairone, once of Countrywide, is a rare midlevel executive found liable in the mortgage crisis.
articles.abstract: Rebecca S. Mairone, once of Countrywide, is a rare midlevel executive found liable in the mortgage crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: Fuld. Cayne. Mozilo. Mairone?

articles.headline: For Victim of Ghastly Crime, a New Face, a New Beginning
articles.snippet: Six years after being beaten and burned beyond recognition, Carmen Tarleton is adjusting to a transplanted face.
articles.abstract: Six years after being beaten and burned beyond recognition, Carmen Tarleton is adjusting to a transplanted face.
articles.lead_paragraph: THETFORD, Vt. — At 1:30 a.m. on Valentine’s Day this year, Carmen Tarleton left her rural home here and drove through the frigid dark to Brigham and Women’s Hospital in Boston. Her doctor had called hours earlier with the news she had been waiting for: a suitable donor had been found. She would get a new face.

articles.headline: Angry Over Syrian War, Saudis Fault U.S. Policy
articles.snippet: Saudi Arabia is threatening to break with the United States and pursue a more robust role in supporting the rebellion against the Syrian government. But officials worry about alienating a friend and helping jihadists.
articles.abstract: Saudi Arabia is threatening to break with the United States and pursue a more robust role in supporting the rebellion against the Syrian government. But officials worry about alienating a friend and helping jihadists.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia — Saudi Arabia has abandoned its traditional policy of discretion in recent weeks, signaling deep anger at the Obama administration’s Middle East policies and threatening to break with its most powerful ally and pursue a more robust and independent role in supporting the rebellion against President Bashar al-Assad of Syria.
articles.byline: By Ben Hubbard and Robert F. Worth

articles.headline: In Spy Uproar, ‘Everyone Does It’ Just Won’t Do
articles.snippet: The uproar in Europe has obscured a new reality: The digital age has merely expanded the ability of nations to do to one another what they have done for centuries.
articles.abstract: The uproar in Europe has obscured a new reality: The digital age has merely expanded the ability of nations to do to one another what they have done for centuries.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The angry protests from Germany’s chancellor over the National Security Agency’s monitoring of her cellphone and France’s furor over the collection of data about millions of its citizens have obscured a new reality: The digital age has merely expanded the ability of nations to do to one another what they have done for centuries.

articles.headline: Goldman Sachs, Buying Redemption
articles.snippet: Via its Goldman Sachs Foundation, led by Dina Powell, the firm many associate with Wall Street greed and excess has staked out a position as one of the nation’s leading corporate philanthropists.
articles.abstract: Via its Goldman Sachs Foundation, led by Dina Powell, the firm many associate with Wall Street greed and excess has staked out a position as one of the nation’s leading corporate philanthropists.
articles.lead_paragraph: Goldman Sachs is a master at making money. Lately it has become a master at giving it away. Goldman — for many a symbol of Wall Street greed and excess — wants the world to know it has a charitable side. With the same calculation that earned it a reputation as the savviest trading house on Wall Street, it has staked out a position as one of the nation’s leading corporate philanthropists, giving away more than $1.6 billion since 2008.

articles.headline: A $13 Billion Reminder of What’s Wrong
articles.snippet: The government’s proposed settlement with JPMorgan Chase offers a teaching moment — about the role banks played in the financial crisis, and risks that remain in the financial system.
articles.abstract: The government’s proposed settlement with JPMorgan Chase offers a teaching moment — about the role banks played in the financial crisis, and risks that remain in the financial system.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was the deal of the week — a possible $13 billion settlement between JPMorgan Chase and the Justice Department to resolve an array of crisis-related mortgage cases.

articles.headline: The E-Cigarette Industry, Waiting to Exhale
articles.snippet: A maker of electronic cigarettes is aiming to bring smokers in from the cold. But it faces health concerns and the might of Big Tobacco, which wants in on the business, too.
articles.abstract: A maker of electronic cigarettes is aiming to bring smokers in from the cold. But it faces health concerns and the might of Big Tobacco, which wants in on the business, too.
articles.lead_paragraph: Geoff Vuleta was in the crowd at a Rolling Stones concert last year when Keith Richards lit up a cigarette on stage, the arena’s no-smoking policy be damned. Feeling inspired, Mr. Vuleta, a longtime smoker, reached into his pocket and pulled one out himself. People seated nearby shot him scolding glances as he inhaled. So he withdrew the cigarette from his mouth and pressed the glowing end to his cheek.

articles.headline: In Fed and Out, Many Now Think Inflation Helps
articles.snippet: Some economists say more inflation is just what the American economy needs to escape from a half-decade of sluggish growth and high unemployment.
articles.abstract: Some economists say more inflation is just what the American economy needs to escape from a half-decade of sluggish growth and high unemployment.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Inflation is widely reviled as a kind of tax on modern life, but as Federal Reserve policy makers prepare to meet this week, there is growing concern inside and outside the Fed that inflation is not rising fast enough.

articles.headline: Gang Rape in India, Routine and Invisible
articles.snippet: The details of a gang rape case in Mumbai reinforce the notion that rape remains a largely invisible crime in India.
articles.abstract: The details of a gang rape case in Mumbai reinforce the notion that rape remains a largely invisible crime in India.
articles.lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India — At 5:30 p.m. on that Thursday, four young men were playing cards, as usual, when Mohammed Kasim Sheikh’s cellphone rang and he announced that it was time to go hunting. Prey had been spotted, he told a friend. When the host asked what they were going to hunt, he said, “A beautiful deer.”
articles.byline: By Ellen Barry and Mansi Choksi

articles.headline: Rice Offers a More Modest Strategy for Mideast
articles.snippet: In an interview, Susan E. Rice, President Obama’s national security adviser, said the president’s goal was to avoid having events in the region swallow his foreign-policy agenda.
articles.abstract: In an interview, Susan E. Rice, President Obama’s national security adviser, said the president’s goal was to avoid having events in the region swallow his foreign-policy agenda.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Each Saturday morning in July and August, Susan E. Rice, President Obama’s new national security adviser, gathered half a dozen aides in her corner office in the White House to plot America’s future in the Middle East. The policy review, a kind of midcourse correction, has set the United States on a new heading in the world’s most turbulent region.

articles.headline: Few Problems With Cannabis for California
articles.snippet: At a time when polls show widening public support for legalizing marijuana, California’s 17-year experience as the first state to legalize medical marijuana offers surprising lessons, experts say.
articles.abstract: At a time when polls show widening public support for legalizing marijuana, California’s 17-year experience as the first state to legalize medical marijuana offers surprising lessons, experts say.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — In the heart of Northern California’s marijuana growing region, the sheriff’s office is inundated each fall with complaints about the stench of marijuana plots or the latest expropriation of public land by growers. Its tranquil communities have been altered by the emergence of a wealthy class of marijuana entrepreneurs, while nearly 500 miles away in Los Angeles, officials have struggled to regulate an explosion of medical marijuana shops.
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney and Rick Lyman

articles.headline: Too Big to Sail? Cruise Ships Face Scrutiny
articles.snippet: After a string of disasters at sea, lawmakers and regulators push for more accountability and question the size of the newest ships.
articles.abstract: After a string of disasters at sea, lawmakers and regulators push for more accountability and question the size of the newest ships.
articles.lead_paragraph: One of the largest cruise ships in 1985 was the 46,000-ton Carnival Holiday. Ten years ago, the biggest, the Queen Mary 2, was three times as large. Today’s record holders are two 225,000-ton ships whose displacement, a measure of a ship’s weight, is about the same as that of a Nimitz-class aircraft carrier.

articles.headline: Gawker Kicks Open the Closet, but Its Disclosure Barely Reverberates
articles.snippet: Now that gay marriage is a fact of life, a person’s sexual orientation is not only not news, it’s not very interesting.
articles.abstract: Now that gay marriage is a fact of life, a person’s sexual orientation is not only not news, it’s not very interesting.
articles.lead_paragraph: What if Gawker tried to out an anchor at Fox News and no one cared?

articles.headline: Twitter Prepares to Feed New Hunger for I.P.O.’s
articles.snippet: The social media giant is entering one of the strongest markets for initial public offerings in three years.
articles.abstract: The social media giant is entering one of the strongest markets for initial public offerings in three years.
articles.lead_paragraph: When it was preparing to go public in 2012, Facebook kindled hopes that the broad interest in the company would accelerate a slow rise in new stock offerings.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and David Gelles

articles.headline: F.D.A. Shift on Painkillers Was Years in the Making
articles.snippet: The F.D.A.’s move to tighten restrictions for prescribing painkillers is a rare victory by lawmakers from states hard hit by prescription drug abuse over well-financed lobbyists for business and patient groups.
articles.abstract: The F.D.A.’s move to tighten restrictions for prescribing painkillers is a rare victory by lawmakers from states hard hit by prescription drug abuse over well-financed lobbyists for business and patient groups.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Heather Dougherty heard the news last week that the Food and Drug Administration had recommended tightening how doctors prescribed the most commonly used narcotic painkillers, she was overjoyed. Fourteen years earlier, her father, Dr. Ronald J. Dougherty, had filed a formal petition urging federal officials to crack down on the drugs.
articles.byline: By Barry Meier and Eric Lipton

articles.headline: Media Outlets Embrace Conferences as Profits Rise
articles.snippet: Once shunned for the fear of implying a casual relationship between journalists and their subjects, live media conferences have now been embraced.
articles.abstract: Once shunned for the fear of implying a casual relationship between journalists and their subjects, live media conferences have now been embraced.
articles.lead_paragraph: Financially struggling media companies are racing to add conferences, festivals and other live events to their business strategy, convinced they can provide a reliable revenue stream and expand the reach of their brands.

articles.headline: Hopes of Market Reforms in China Tempered by Political Realities
articles.snippet: “Plan 383,” a government research body’s proposal to liberalize parts of the economy, has attracted attention, but experts call sweeping changes unlikely.
articles.abstract: “Plan 383,” a government research body’s proposal to liberalize parts of the economy, has attracted attention, but experts call sweeping changes unlikely.
articles.lead_paragraph: China’s leaders head toward a major policy-setting conference next month bearing heady expectations that they have encouraged, and a proposal from a prominent government research organization has magnified speculation that they will embrace bold pro-market overhauls.
